title: Network Science-Based Mathematical Collaborative Learning Design: Application of Graph Theory and Dynamic Analysis

context.prior_knowledge: Experience with online learning platforms, understanding of graph theory (nodes/edges/centrality) and basic statistics (mean/variance/correlation coefficients), and collaborative learning experience
context.additional_context: Enhancing online community operation and analysis capabilities to promote collaborative learning in mathematics for practicing professionals. Cultivating data-driven decision-making skills using network science and mathematical modeling techniques (graph theory, statistical analysis), with special focus on efficient sharing of mathematical expressions (formulas/graphs).

learning_goals: Design a strategy (node connection optimization model) applying Graph Theory to activate mathematical content creation interactions among learners in online learning communities by over 80%

Learners analyze three or more network datasets using Gephi, visualize mathematical content consumption patterns (text/equation frequency), and identify three main consumption types (concentrated, dispersed, hybrid) based on edge weight and centrality metrics (degree, betweenness centrality)

Learners collect three months of learning group interaction data (100+ participants) using Python-based network analysis tools (NetworkX, Gephi), analyze dynamic changes in network density (%) and centrality metrics (degree, betweenness centrality) over time, and produce a 15-page dynamic network report

Derive graph-based optimization models for mathematical collaborative learning design principles by calculating Pearson’s correlation coefficients (r) among three interaction types (creation/consumption/organization)
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
